0: Image caption Mohammed Zaman was owner of the Indian Garden restaurant in Easingwold where Paul Wilson ordered a takeaway curry NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A restaurant owner accused of killing a customer who died from an allergic reaction to a curry "put profit before safety", a court has heard. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Paul Wilson, 38, suffered a severe anaphylactic shock in January 2014 after eating a takeaway from the Indian Garden in Easingwold, North Yorkshire. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mohammed Zaman, 52, of Aylesham Court, Huntington, denies manslaughter. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The restaurant boss "cut corners at every turn", Teesside Crown Court heard. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR When Mr Wilson ordered a takeaway meal from the restaurant, he had made it clear it must be nut-free, the jury heard. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The court was told "no nuts" was written on the order chit and on the lid of the curry he took to his home in Helperby, near Thirsk. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He was found dead later the same evening. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 'Ignored all warnings' NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The jury heard Mr Zaman took a "reckless and cavalier attitude to risk" at the restaurants he owned. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Richard Wright QC, prosecuting, told the court Mr Zaman had swapped from using almond powder to the cheaper groundnut powder, containing peanuts, in June 2013. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Despite a warning from his supplier, the prosecutor said, the restaurateur did not warn customers he was using peanut ingredients. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Google Image caption The Indian Garden restaurant pictured in 2011 NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A week before Mr Wilson's death, Mr Wright said, a trading standards officer found evidence of peanuts in another meal which was said to have been peanut-free, and discovered a box labelled blanched ground peanut in the kitchen of Mr Zaman's Jaipur Spice restaurant in Easingwold. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The officer told staff all customers must be informed chefs were using peanuts, the court heard. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Mohammed Zaman received numerous warnings that he was putting his customers' health, and potentially their lives, at risk," Mr Wright said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Tragically for Paul Wilson, Mohammed Zaman took none of those opportunities and ignored all of the warnings he was given." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The prosecution said the restaurateur knew the food he served "posed a serious health risk".
